and peaceful assembly"}]]}]]}]]}]]}],["$","section",null,{"className":"max-w-7xl mx-auto px-4 sm:px-6 lg:px-8 py-8 sm:py-12","children":["$","$L3",null,{"scenario":{"id":"protest-assembly","title":"Protest & Assembly Rights","icon":"✊","category":"Civic Duty","description":"What to know about your rights when participating in protests and peaceful assembly","phrases":["We are peacefully assembling on public property.","Am I being detained or am I free to go?","I choose to remain silent.","I want to speak to a lawyer.","I need medical attention."],"rights":[{"title":"Right to Peaceful Assembly","description":"The First Amendment protects your right to peacefully gather with others to express your views through protests, marches, and demonstrations. This includes the right to assemble on public sidewalks, streets, and parks. However, authorities may impose reasonable time, place, and manner restrictions that apply equally to all groups regardless of viewpoint.","source":"1st Amendment - Right to Peaceably Assemble","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Strong protections for protesters; permits cannot be denied based on content; reasonable fees only"},{"state":"NY","note":"NYC requires permits for large gatherings but allows spontaneous protests; strong judicial oversight"},{"state":"TX","note":"Some cities require permits for protests; viewpoint-neutral requirements enforced by courts"},{"state":"FL","note":"HB 1 (2021) increased penalties for protest-related offenses; legal challenges ongoing"}]},{"title":"Right to Record Police","description":"You have the constitutional right to record police officers performing their duties in public spaces. This is protected by the First Amendment as a form of free speech and expression. You may record video and audio, but you cannot interfere with police operations or violate other laws while recording.","source":"1st Amendment - Free Speech; Glik v. Cunniffe (2011)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Explicit statutory protection for recording police; civil remedies available for violations"},{"state":"NY","note":"Second Circuit strongly affirmed right to record police in public; police cannot confiscate devices"},{"state":"TX","note":"Right to record established; wiretap laws don't apply to public recordings"},{"state":"FL","note":"Can record police in public spaces; two-party consent law doesn't apply to public recordings"}]},{"title":"Right to Not Disperse Immediately","description":"Police cannot order protesters to disperse without a lawful reason. Before dispersal, officers must provide clear notice of the order, a reasonable opportunity to comply, and a clear exit path. An order to disperse must be specific and cannot target protesters based on their message.","source":"1st Amendment; Ward v. Rock Against Racism (1989)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Must give clear warning and reasonable time to disperse; failure to do so may invalidate arrests"},{"state":"NY","note":"Police must announce dispersal order audibly; protesters must be given opportunity to leave"},{"state":"TX","note":"Disobeying lawful dispersal order is a misdemeanor; order must be lawful and properly given"},{"state":"UT","note":"Failure to disperse requires lawful order; protesters have right to know why dispersal is ordered"}]},{"title":"Right to Legal Observer","description":"Legal observers—trained volunteers who monitor protests and document police conduct—have the same rights as other protesters. They cannot be singled out or arrested merely for observing and documenting. Wearing identifiable legal observer clothing (often green hats) signals their role to police.","source":"1st Amendment; Legal observer programs (National Lawyers Guild)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Legal observers explicitly protected; cannot be targeted for monitoring police conduct"},{"state":"NY","note":"NLG legal observers well-established; wearing green hat provides recognizable protection"},{"state":"TX","note":"Legal observers have same rights as press; documentation is protected activity"}]},{"title":"Right to Medical Attention","description":"If you are injured during a protest, police have a duty to provide or facilitate medical care. You cannot be denied medical attention because you are under arrest. If you see someone injured, you can call for medical help without fear of arrest for making the call.","source":"Due Process Clause; Estelle v. Gamble (1976)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Police must provide medical care to injured arrestees; failure can result in civil liability"},{"state":"NY","note":"NYC has specific protocols for medical care during protests; EMTs should have access"},{"state":"TX","note":"Medical care must be provided to those in custody; deliberate indifference is constitutional violation"}]}]},"availableStates":["CA","FL","NY","TX","UT"]}]}],"$L4"]}],null,"$L5"]}],"loading":null,"isPartial":false}
